caption: √âtienne Marcel was provost of the merchants of Paris under King John II of France, called John the Good. He distinguished himself in the defense of the small craftsmen and guildsmen who made up most of the city population.

The Statue d'√âtienne Marcel is an equestrian statue of √âtienne Marcel, the Provost of the Merchants of Paris from 1355 to 1358. It is located on the south side of the H√¥tel de Ville de Paris, in the 4th arrondissement of Paris.  The statue was commissioned in 1882 and was completed in 1888. It was created by the sculptors Jean-Antoine-Marie Idrac and Laurent Marqueste. Idrac died in 1884, so Marqueste completed the statue based on Idrac's sketches and models.  The statue depicts Marcel in full armor, mounted on a rearing horse. He is holding a sword in his right hand and a scroll in his left hand. The scroll is inscribed with the words "Pour le salut du peuple" (For the salvation of the people).  Marcel was a popular figure in Paris during the 14th century. He was a champion of the common people and led a revolt against the dauphin, Charles, in 1358. He was assassinated by royalist supporters shortly after the revolt was crushed.  The Statue d'√âtienne Marcel is a reminder of Marcel's role in the history of Paris. It is also a symbol of the city's commitment to democracy and social justice.

Time of visit: second half of March 2014. When you pass or approach from the south side of the Hotel de Ville, you come across the Stefano Marcelo Monument. It is an imposing equestrian statue and you will surely like it.

√âtienne Marcel (Paris, 1315 ‚Äì Paris, 31 July 1358) was a French politician. Scion of one of the most powerful bourgeois families in Paris, √âtienne joined the two major Parisian brotherhoods, the Great Brotherhood of Our Lady (Grande-Confr√©rie de Notre Dame) and the Brotherhood of Saint James of the Pilgrims (Confr√©rie Saint-Jacques- aux-P√®lerins). In 1354 he became pr√©v√¥t des marchands, that is, head of the Parisian municipality. Importer of clothes from Flanders and Brussels, he was also a supplier to the royal court. He is in control of the States General of 1355 together with the bishop of Laon, Robert Le Coq.

In the middle of the 100 Years' War, conflict between French and English. √âtienne Marcel is assassinated by the Parisians who accuse him of having gone too far in his opposition to the French monarchy and is accused of having wanted to hand over the city to the English.  How has the city of Paris not yet removed the statue of this traitor to the nation!?!
